step_by_step_thinking: The patient presents with nail pitting, joint swelling (knees and back), and a history of arthritis. Nail pitting is a hallmark of psoriatic arthritis (Document [0][7]). Psoriatic arthritis often involves peripheral arthritis (Document [2]) and axial involvement like sacroiliitis (Document [10]). The presence of dandruff is less relevant here. Rheumatoid arthritis typically shows symmetric joint involvement and positive rheumatoid factor, which isn't mentioned. Arthritis mutilans is a severe form with osteolysis, not fitting the patient's presentation. Mixed connective tissue disease isn't strongly supported by the nail findings. The CASPAR criteria (Document [0]) align with psoriatic arthritis.
